A block of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> is pulled across a rough horizontal table by a string connected to a motor that is attached to the floor. The string passes over a pulley with negligible friction that is vertically aligned with the left edge of the table as shown. The string and pulley both have negligible mass. The pulley is at height <math alttext="H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>H</mi></math> above the table. The motor exerts a constant force of tension <math alttext="F sub T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>T</mi></msub></math> on the string, and the block remains in contact with the table at all times as the block slides across the table from <math alttext="x equals L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>L</mi></math> to <math alttext="x equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the table and the block is <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></math>. Express all algebraic answers in terms of <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math>, <math alttext="H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>H</mi></math>, <math alttext="F sub T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>T</mi></msub></math>, <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>, <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></math>, <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math>, and physical constants as appropriate. (a) On the dot below that represents the block, draw and label the forces (not components) that act on the block when the block is at <math alttext="x equals L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>L</mi></math>. Each force must be represented by a distinct arrow starting on, and pointing away from, the dot.

frqParts.text: Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A block of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> is pulled across a rough horizontal table by a string connected to a motor that is attached to the floor. The string passes over a pulley with negligible friction that is vertically aligned with the left edge of the table as shown. The string and pulley both have negligible mass. The pulley is at height <math alttext="H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>H</mi></math> above the table. The motor exerts a constant force of tension <math alttext="F sub T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>T</mi></msub></math> on the string, and the block remains in contact with the table at all times as the block slides across the table from <math alttext="x equals L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>L</mi></math> to <math alttext="x equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the table and the block is <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></math>. Express all algebraic answers in terms of <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math>, <math alttext="H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>H</mi></math>, <math alttext="F sub T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>T</mi></msub></math>, <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>, <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></math>, <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math>, and physical constants as appropriate. (a) On the dot below that represents the block, draw and label the forces (not components) that act on the block when the block is at <math alttext="x equals L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>L</mi></math>. Each force must be represented by a distinct arrow starting on, and pointing away from, the dot.

(b) Derive an expression for the angle <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math> that the string makes with the horizontal as a function of <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>.

(c)i. Derive an expression for the normal force <math alttext="F sub N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>N</mi></msub></math> exerted on the block by the table as a function of the block’s position <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>.

ii. Derive an expression for the magnitude of the net horizontal force <math alttext="F sub net" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>net</mtext></msub></math> exerted on the block as a function of the position <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>.

(d) Write, but do not solve, an integral expression that could be used to solve for the work <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>W</mi></math> done by the string on the block as the block moves from <math alttext="x equals L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>L</mi></math> to <math alttext="x equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>.

(e) Does the string do more, less, or the same amount of work on the block as the block moves from <math alttext="x equals L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>L</mi></math> to <math alttext="x equals L over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mi>L</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle></math> compared to when the block moves from <math alttext="x equals L over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mi>L</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="x equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> ?______ More work when the block moves from <math alttext="x equals L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>L</mi></math> to <math alttext="x equals L over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mi>L</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle></math>______ Less work when the block moves from <math alttext="x equals L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>L</mi></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="x equals L over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mi>L</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle></math>______ The same amount of work when the block moves from <math alttext="x equals L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>L</mi></math> to <math alttext="x equals L over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mi>L</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle></math>Justify your answer.
